Elliotte Harold wrote:

> Stephen Smith wrote:
>  > If you're considering testing a private method, doesn't that tell you
>  > something about your design? If a method is private and sufficiently
>  > important that you want to test it, perhaps the class in question needs
>  > to be refactored in order to improve its testability.
> 
> No, it doesn't. The method can either be reached through the public API
> (in which case test that) or it can be eliminated. There's no reason you
> have to invoke a method directly to test it.

As usual, a better answer is somewhere in between.

If you want to test a private method by invoking it directly, then it 
/might/ be a sign that that method belongs on someone's public 
interface, such as a new class. If, after reflection, the method really 
should remain private, then you should probably test it through the 
available public method(s) that invoke it. If you have no remaining 
alternative, then consider using something like JUnitX.

As an example, if multiple public methods invoke the same private 
method, it's /possible/ that that private method would be better placed 
on a new class's public interface. This, however, is just a guideline.

It is instructive to take one section of your codebase and apply the 
rule "All directly tested methods must be public". It will teach you 
interesting things about object-oriented design, even if the result is 
not necessarily the best (or even a good) design.

I find when I'm starting out that it's easier to follow simple rules, 
then learn when to break those rules. For that reason, I applied the 
"all directly tested methods must be public" rule to a couple of 
codebases and learned a lot. This helped me arrive at my current opinion 
on the subject.

I will emphasize, though, that one should remember what Elliotte has 
written above: /not all/ methods /must/ be tested by direct invocation.

Take care.
